newsitem.title: USA: Passenger jet lands without nose gear in New York.
newsitem.headline: Passenger jet lands without nose gear in New York.

text.p: An American Airlines MD-80 with no front wheels made an emergency landing at John F. Kennedy International Airport Monday night, officials said.
Three people suffered minor injuries as the jet bumped down the runway and skidded to a halt, said Andrea Rader, a spokeswoman for American Airlines, a unit of AMR Corp.

American Airlines Flight 346 was flying from Chicago to New York's La Guardia airport with 88 passengers and crew of five when a landing gear warning light started flashing, a New York Port Authority spokesman said.
After flying past the La Guardia control tower to confirm the wheel were not deployed, the plane was diverted to JFK airport as a precaution because it has longer runways than La Guardia, he said.
The McDonnell Douglas Super 80 landed on runway 31-R at 10:30 EST and skidded to a halt. The pilot deployed the evacuation shutes and the passengers got off, he said.
"It was a rough ride down the runway, but there was no fire," the spokesman said.
Airport emergency crews sprayed foam on a section of the plane's nose.
JFK airport was closed for 30 minutes, after which its three other runways were back in operation.
"We have three injuries. They are all minor," Rader told Reuters. She could not identify the injured passengers.
One passenger had a leg injury and another a foot injury, while the third suffered an asthma complication and was being treated in hospital.
"As they were approaching La Guardia airport, they got an unsafe nose-gear warning light," the New York Port Authority spokesman said.
"They did a fly-by of La Guardia control tower and the controllers confirmed to them that the nose gear was not down," he added.
Rader said "(The pilot) apparently did a great job landing the plane and obviously put the nose down last."
